Award.AwardTitle: Precision Measurements with Cold and Ultracold Neutrons
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports precision measurements with cold neutrons that serve to better understand the fundamental interactions between elementary particles. With the first sub-project, the Nab spectrometer, a precision study of neutron beta decay is planned. The spectrometer is in the construction phase, and with this grant the PI's group's efforts in magnet design, systematic studies, the construction of the main electrode system, the vacuum system, and a monoenergetic proton source are supported. The second sub-project, the npdgamma experiment, aims to better understand weak hadronic interactions. The experiment has entered the data taking phase at the cold neutron beamline FNPB of the Spallation Neutron Source. This grant supports the PI's group's contribution to magnetic field environment, data taking and data analysis.

The common goal of this experimental program is to test the Standard Model in regions which were not accessible before, or at least not as precise. A discovery of something not explained in the Standard Model would also have important implications for High Energy Physics and Cosmology. The project have a valuable impact on higher education: most of the work is done by students at undergraduate and graduate level and postdocs, who earn valuable skills and experiences for their future career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supports precision measurements with cold neutrons which serve to better understand the fundamental interactions between elementary particles. With the first sub-project, the Nab spectrometer, a precision study of neutron beta decay is planned. The PI is the experiment manager. A description of the theory of operation of the spectrometer and its expected performance has been published as part of a larger review in J. Phys. G. in 2014, with the PI being the lead author. An experimental highlight of the PI’s group’s work was the identification of a new type of surface coating for the internal electrode system that promises to reduce unwanted electric fields inside the neutron decay spectrometer. Another highlight is the development of an ultra-stable low-energy proton source that will be needed for the calibration of the Nab detector; the stability achieved is <300 ppm/hour. The Nab experiment has started installation at the Fundamental Physics Beamline of the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Lab, and the collaboration is looking forward to the start commissioning and taking physics data maybe in a year from now.

Furthermore, this grant supported data taking and analysis of the npdgamma experiment, which measures the gamma asymmetry in the (n,p) reaction with respect to the neutron spin, and which is used to determine the strength of the one-pion exchange component of hadronic weak interaction. The experiment is now finished, and its data analysis is nearing completion.

The outcomes of this research have been published in various publications that are listed in the project final report; other publications – in particular the ones with the final result of npdgamma – are still in preparation.

The NSF grant made a major impact in the education of students. Two graduate students are supporting the work on the design, construction, and systematics studies of the Nab spectrometer. The proton source was first conceived as an undergraduate research project, and fourteen undergraduate students worked on the project. Americo Salas Bacci, research scientist, has taken over the project lead; he deserves most of the credit for the proton source optimization, and he gained valuable mentorship experience with many of the students, which is supporting his applications for permanent scientist positions. Furthermore, two undergraduate students have worked on the design, construction, and commissioning of a Stern-Gerlach filter for the GRANIT experiment (the study of gravitationally bound neutrons in quantum states), and one of them (a female) has received the annual Undergraduate Research Prize of the Physics Department for the best undergraduate research of the graduating class of 2016.
